senses.de: Something that is boring and takes a lot of time
senses.ex: The data entry job was tedious and monotonous.

Tips.title: Feeling of Boredom
Tips.description: Use to describe tasks that are so uninteresting they make you feel weary and impatient.
Tips.example: Copying numbers into a spreadsheet all day is tedious.

Tips.title: Negative Connotation
Tips.description: 'Tedious' often implies a negative feeling towards the task or activity.
Tips.example: He found the lecture tedious and couldn't wait for it to end.

Tips.title: Not Inherently Negative
Tips.description: Sometimes 'tedious' just states the nature of a task without judging its importance.
Tips.example: Proofreading is tedious, but crucial for a flawless essay.

senses.de: Something that is complicated with unnecessary details
senses.ex: The report was tedious with too many irrelevant details.

Tips.title: Unnecessary Detail
Tips.description: Emphasize the inclusion of too much extraneous information that overwhelms the main point.
Tips.example: Her explanation was so tedious that the main instructions were lost.

Tips.title: Academic Context
Tips.description: Often used to describe complex materials that are difficult to digest in academic settings.
Tips.example: The scholarly article was tedious and required multiple readings.

Tips.title: Precision of Language
Tips.description: Use 'tedious' to suggest a task could be streamlined or made more efficient.
Tips.example: Compiling this data manually is tedious; isn't there an automated method?

senses.de: Something that takes a long time and patience
senses.ex: Planting seeds is a tedious but necessary task.

Tips.title: Time and Patience
Tips.description: Stress both the duration and the need for continued effort or endurance.
Tips.example: Learning a new language can be a tedious process, requiring daily practice.

Tips.title: Reluctant Acceptance
Tips.description: Shows recognition of a task's tediousness while also acknowledging its necessity.
Tips.example: Sorting through old files is tedious but necessary for organizing my office.

Tips.title: Personal Perspective
Tips.description: Remember 'tedious' may be subjective; what is tedious for one may not be for another.
Tips.example: Some find knitting tedious, yet others find it relaxing and rewarding.

Bore.wordDefinition:
Bore is used when something is not interesting or engaging, and makes you feel restless or uninterested. It usually refers to a particular activity, person or thing that is simply unentertaining.

Tedious implies something is long, dull, repetitive, and exhausting due to the tedium of routine or monotony. It refers to activities that are generally boring and tiresome because they require a lot of time, attention or patience.

The main difference between the two words is that bore refers to something that is uninteresting, whereas tedious refers to something that is monotonous, repetitive, and wears you out because it's a long-term task.

Dull.wordDefinition:
Dull refers to something that lacks excitement or interest. For example, a lecture might be described as dull if it's boring, unengaging or uninteresting.

So, while dull refers to lack of excitement or interest, tedious refers to the weariness caused by boredom or the tedium (boredom) of repetition.

Interesting.wordDefinition:
Interesting and tedious are words with opposite meanings. Interesting means something that is engaging, fascinating or intriguing.

It often refers to something that excites curiosity or arouses interest in people. For example, an interesting book or movie captures the attention of the audience and keeps them engaged.

Tedious means something that is boring, uninteresting or monotonous. It often refers to something that is repetitive and seems to go on forever, making it dull or tiresome.

We can use the word interesting to describe things that appeal to us or catch our attention, while we use tedious to describe things that bore us or make us feel tired.

Monotonous.wordDefinition:
Monotonous means something is repetitive and unchanging, lacking variety or excitement. It refers to a situation or activity that becomes boring because it is always the same.

For example, a job that involves doing the same task over and over again can be described as monotonous.

Both words describe situations that can be boring, but monotonous refers to a lack of variety, while tedious refers to a lack of interest.

If something is repetitively boring, it is monotonous, and if something is boring because it requires a lot of effort and attention, it is tedious.

Tire.wordDefinition:
Tedious means boring or dull, something that seems to continue for a long time and becomes monotonous or tiresome. For example, a tedious lecture or a tedious day at work.

Tire means to feel exhausted or fatigued. It is a feeling of physical or mental fatigue due to exertion or prolonged stress.

For example, if you've been running for a long time, you'll eventually tire and need to take a break.

Tedious describes something that is boring or repetitive, while tire describes a feeling of exhaustion or fatigue.

Tiresome.wordDefinition:
Both tedious and tiresome refer to something that is boring or unpleasant, but they have slightly different connotations.

Tiresome means something that is causing fatigue, annoyance, or frustration. For example, listening to someone complain constantly can be tiresome.

Tedious relates to the process or activity, while tiresome relates to the emotional or physical response to it.

Wearisome.wordDefinition:
Both tedious and wearisome refer to something that is dull or tiresome.

However, tedious describes something that is repetitive and boring, while wearisome describes something that is physically or mentally exhausting.

A long hike through rough terrain could be described as wearisome because it is physically exhausting.

quotes.Text: Much protective self-criticism stems from growing up around people who wouldn't or couldn't love you, and it's likely they still can't or won't. In general, however, the more you let go of the tedious delusion of your own unattractiveness, the easier it will be for others to connect with you, and the more accepted you'll feel.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Martha Beck

quotes.Text: I did a very stupid diet where you have three food groups, and you never eat them together. It's so bloody tedious; I'm losing the will to live just describing it. I managed to stay very thin because you spent your life wandering around starving hungry looking for a chickpea to go with a chicken leg.
quotes.Title: English Comedian
quotes.Name: Ben Miller

quotes.Text: Long runs are definitely tedious, but I find that timing is important on them. I like to do my long runs either early in the morning as the sun rises or in the late afternoon when the sun sets because it gives me something to see instead of thinking about how long I'm running.
quotes.Title: American Celebrity
quotes.Name: Andi Dorfman

quotes.Text: Science fiction rarely is about scientists doing real science, in its slowness, its vagueness, the sort of tedious quality of getting out there and digging amongst rocks and then trying to convince people that what you're seeing justifies the conclusions you're making.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Kim Stanley Robinson

quotes.Text: To learn a piece on the piano - even a simple one - has proved every bit as agonizing as writing a chapter in a book, every bit as tedious and hopeless and halting. But this is not to say that the piano hasn't helped my writing. It has, just not in the ways I expected.
quotes.Title: American Writer
quotes.Name: Ben Dolnick

quotes.Text: When you're in danger of losing a thing it becomes precious and when it's around us, it's in tedious abundance and we take it for granted as if we're going to live forever, which we're not.
quotes.Title: Irish Writer
quotes.Name: John McGahern

quotes.Text: Characters develop as the book progresses, but any that start to bore me end up in the wastepaper basket. In real life, we may have to put up with tedious people, but not in novels.
quotes.Title: English Journalist
quotes.Name: Laurie Graham

quotes.Text: Surely a long life must be somewhat tedious, since we are forced to call in so many trifling things to help rid us of our time, which will never return.
quotes.Title: English Writer
quotes.Name: Samuel Johnson

quotes.Text: Truth, after all, wears a different face to everybody, and it would be too tedious to wait till all were agreed.
quotes.Title: American Poet
quotes.Name: James Russell Lowell

quotes.Text: Being on television, playing the same character for many years, for me, I think that would get a little tedious.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Peter Dinklage
